Description: Short elongated wooden pin, pointed at one end, where it is broken off. Circular to oval in section. The other end is thicker and roughly finished. The area where both parts meet, four thin incised lines are forming three bands in relief, two further incised lines that are less deep carved. Through the head and about through three quarters of the pointed end runs a perforation, probably from the original plant. Clothes pin or hair pin?
Acquisition notes: Formerly housed by the Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery and the EES London.
